[[Image:Venetian_Patent_Statute_1474.png|thumb|right|220px|The Venetian Patent Statute, enacted by the Senate of Venice in 1474, is widely accepted to be the basis for the earliest patent system in the world.]] The '''Venetian Patent Statute''' of March 19, 1474, established in the [[Republic of Venice]] the first [[statutory]] [[patent]] system in Europe, and may be deemed to be the earliest codified patent system in the world.<ref name="Ladas">{{cite book|last=Ladas|first=Stephen Pericles|title=Patents, Trademarks, and Related Rights: National and International Protection, Volume 1|year=1975|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674657755|pages=6-7}}</ref><ref name=Teich>{{cite book|editor1-last=Teich|editor1-first=Mikulas |editor-link1=Mikulas Teich |editor2-last=Porter|editor2-first= Roy |editor-link2=Roy Porter |title=The Industrial Revolution in National Context: Europe and the USA|year=1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|page=160|isbn=9780521409407}}</ref> The Statute is written in old [[Venetian dialect]].<ref name="Ladas"/> It provided that patents might be granted for "any [[novelty (patent)|new]] and ingenious device, not previously made", provided it was useful.<ref name="Kostylo">Kostylo, J. (2008) ‘[http://www.copyrighthistory.org/cam/tools/request/showRecord?id=commentary_i_1474 Commentary on the Venetian Statute on Industrial Brevets (1474)]', in Primary Sources on Copyright (1450–1900), eds L. Bently & M. Kretschmer, www.copyrighthistory.org</ref> By and large, these principles still remain the basic principles of patent law.<ref name="Kostylo"/>
==Significance== The dominant view among historians and legal scholars is that the Venetian Patent Act provides the legal foundation of the modern patent system.<ref name="Mandich">Mandich, Giulio. "Venetian Patents (1450-1550)." J. Pat. Off. Soc'y 30 (1948): 166 (translated by F.D. Prager).</ref>{{Request quotation|date=October 2017}} Meshbesher observing "the impact of the Venetian patent law and practice on the history of patent law has been studied by several authors and is well-recognized, hence the first ''patent statute'' [author's emphasis] is usually considered to be the one was enacted (''sic'') in the Republic of Venice in 1474".<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Meshbesher|first=Thomas M.|date=1996|title=The Role of History in Comparative Patent Law|url=|journal=J. Pat. & Trademark Off. Soc'y|volume=78|pages=595 at footnote 3.|via=}}</ref>
The most widely accepted<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Mgbeoji|first=Ikechi|date=2003|title=The Juridical Origins of the International Patent System: Towards a Histiography of the Role of Patents in Industrialization|url=http://digitalcommons.osgoode.yorku.ca/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1888&context=scholarly_works|journal=Journal of the History of International Law|volume=5.2|pages=413|via=}}</ref> translation of the old Venetian dialect original is reproduced below.
{{cquote|[T]here are in this city, and also there come temporarily by reason of its greatness and goodness, men from different places and most clever minds, capable of devising and inventing all manner of ingenious contrivances. And should it be provided,that the works and contrivances invented by them, others having seen them could not make them and take their honor, men of such kind would exert their minds, invent and make things which would be of no small utility and benefit to our State.Therefore, decision will be passed that, by authority of this Council, each person who will make in this city any new ingenious contrivance, not made heretofore in our dominion, as soon as it is reduced to perfection, so that it can be used and exercised, shall give notice of the same to the office of our Provisioners of Common. It being forbidden to any other in any territory and place of ours to make any other contrivance in the form and resemblance thereof, without the consent and license of the author up to ten years. And, however, should anybody make it, the aforesaid author and inventor will have the liberty to cite him before any office of this city, by which office the aforesaid who shall infringe be forced to pay him the sum of one hundred ducates and the contrivance immediately destroyed. Being then in liberty of our Government at his will to take and use in his need any of the said contrivances and instruments, with this condition, however, that no others than the authors shall exercise them.<ref name=":1" />}}
One leading patent scholar also stating that "the international patent experience of nearly 500 years has merely brought amendments or improvements upon the solid core established in Renaissance Venice".<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Genesis Of American Patent and Copyright|last=Bugbee|first=Bruce|publisher=Public Affairs Press|year=1964|isbn=|location=Washington DC|pages=24}}</ref>
Some historians question this dominant view and claim that the Venetian Patent Statute of 1474 "functioned primarily as a codification of prior customs [and] did not introduce new principles.<ref name="Kostylo" /> "Neither did it mark the beginnings of the modern patent system."<ref name="Kostylo" /> According to Joanna Kostylo, "[i]t should best understood as declaratory instrument codifying existing general principles and customs of granting patent rights for innovations in Venice".<ref name="Kostylo" /> Accordingly she states that the significance of the Venetian statute lies "in its broad and general character," in the sense that it attempted to "apply general rules to the granting of patents rather than conferring occasional individual favours (gratiae) in response to individual petitions."<ref name="Kostylo" /> It is also significant that the "legislation focuse[d] on protecting and rewarding individual inventors, in contrast to monopolies reserved to organized groups ([[guilds]])."<ref name="Kostylo" />
This alternative view is hard to reconcile with the large shift in patenting activity observed after 1474.<ref name="Mandich" />{{Request quotation|date=October 2017}} As observed by Allan Gomme former librarian of the UK Patent Office "there was, then, a regular practice of granting patents in Venice which began about 1475..".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Patents of Invention Origins and Growth of the Patent System in Britain|last=Gomme|first=Allan|publisher=Longmans Green and Co|year=1946|isbn=|location=London|pages=7}}</ref> See also Statistics, below. The majority view remains that the Venetian Patent Statute marked a watershed moment and was indeed the first basis for a patent system, notwithstanding earlier isolated patents having been issued.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mgbeoji|first=Ikechi|date=2003|title=The Juridicial Origins of the International Patent System: Towards a Histiography of the Role of Patents in Industrialization|url=http://digitalcommons.osgoode.yorku.ca/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1888&context=scholarly_works|journal=Journal of the History of International Law|volume=5.2|pages=414|via=}}</ref>
==Statistics== Between 1474 and 1788, the [[Venetian Senate]] granted about 2000 patents: 28 between 1474 and 1500, 593 between 1500 and 1600, 605 between 1600 and 1700, and 670 between 1700 and 1788.<ref name=Teich/> Venetian patents were granted free of payment, "which explains their relatively high number".<ref name=Teich/>
==See also== *[[Filippo Brunelleschi]], famous [[Florence|Florentine]] architect and engineer, who claimed ownership over engineering techniques against "corporatist interests and monopoly of the guilds." In 1421, he effectively obtained a patent for a cargo boat. The [[Republic of Florence]] granted him a three-year exclusive right on his invention in exchange for disclosing it to the public.<ref name="Kostylo"/> The cargo boat sank on its first voyage on the river [[Arno]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Early American Law of Intellectual Property : The Historical Foundations of The United States Patent and Copyright Systems|last=Bugbee|first=Bruce|publisher=|year=1961|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>

{{Expert-subject|Law|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Washington v. Glucksberg |ArgueDate=January 8 |ArgueYear=1997 |DecideDate=June 26 |DecideYear=1997 |FullName=Washington, et al., Petitioners v. Harold Glucksberg, et al. |USVol=521 |USPage=702 |ParallelCitations=117 S. Ct. 2258; 117 S. Ct. 2302; 138 [[Lawyers' Edition|L. Ed. 2d]] 772; 1997 [[LexisNexis|U.S. LEXIS]] 4039; 65 U.S.L.W. 4669; 97 Cal. Daily Op. Service 5008; 97 Daily Journal DAR 8150; 11 Fla. L. Weekly Fed. S 190 |Prior=850 [[F. Supp.]] [https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/850/1454/2132465/ 1454] ([[W.D. Wash.]] 1994); reversed, 49 [[F.3d]] [https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/49/586/550843/ 586] ([[9th Cir.]] 1995); reversed on rehearing en banc, 79 [[F.3d]] [https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/79/790/556505/ 790] (9th Cir. 1996). |Subsequent= |Holding=[[Due Process Clause]] does not protect the right to assistance in committing suicide. |SCOTUS=1994-2005 |Majority=Rehnquist |JoinMajority=O'Connor, Scalia, Kennedy, Thomas |Concurrence=O'Connor |JoinConcurrence=Ginsburg, Breyer |Concurrence2=Stevens |Concurrence3=Souter |Concurrence4=Ginsburg |Concurrence5=Breyer |LawsApplied= }} '''''Washington v. Glucksberg''''', 521 U.S. 702 (1997),<ref>{{ussc|name=Washington v. Glucksberg|volume=521|page=702|year=1997}}.</ref> was a [[List of landmark court decisions in the United States|landmark]] case in which the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] unanimously held that a right to [[assisted suicide in the United States]] was not protected by the [[Due Process Clause]].
==Background== Dr. Harold Glucksberg, a physician; four other physicians; three terminally-ill patients; and the non-profit organization Compassion in Dying challenged [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington State]]'s ban against assisted suicide in the Natural Death Act of 1979. They claimed that [[assisted suicide]] was a liberty interest protected by the Due Process Clause of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]].
On May 3, 1994, US District Court Judge [[Barbara Jacobs Rothstein]] ruled in favor of Glucksberg.<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Compassion in Dying v. Washington |vol=850 |reporter=F. Supp. |opinion=1454 |pinpoint= |court=[[W.D. Wash.]] |date=1994 |url=https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/850/1454/2132465/ |accessdate=2018-07-22 |quote=}}</ref> On March 9, 1995, however, the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit]] reversed, with Judge [[John T. Noonan Jr.]] joined by [[Diarmuid O'Scannlain]].<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Compassion in Dying v. Washington |vol=49 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=586 |pinpoint= |court=[[9th Cir.]] |date=1995 |url=https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/49/586/550843/ |accessdate=2018-07-22 |quote=}}</ref> Then, after rehearing the case ''[[en banc]]'', the Ninth Circuit on May 28, 1996, reversed the earlier panel and affirmed the District Court's decision, in an opinion by Judge [[Stephen Reinhardt]].<ref>{{cite court |litigants=Compassion in Dying v. Washington |vol=79 |reporter=F.3d |opinion=790 |pinpoint= |court=[[9th Cir.]] |date=1996 |url=https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F3/79/790/556505/ |accessdate=2018-07-22 |quote=}}</ref>
Washington Attorney General [[Christine Gregoire]] petitioned the Supreme Court for a writ of [[certiorari]], which was granted. The case was argued before the Supreme Court on January 8, 1997. [[Walter E. Dellinger III]], the acting [[Solicitor General of the United States]], appeared as an ''[[amicus curiae]]'', urging reversal.<ref>[https://www.oyez.org/cases/1996/96-110 "Washington v. Glucksberg."] Oyez, Accessed 24 Apr. 2017.</ref> The question presented was whether the protection of the Due Process Clause included a right to commit suicide and to commit suicide with another's assistance.
==Decision== [[William Rehnquist|Chief Justice Rehnquist]] wrote the majority opinion for the court. His decision reversed the Ninth Circuit's decision that the ban on physician-assisted suicide was a violation of the Due Process Clause. The Court held that because assisted suicide is not a fundamental liberty interest, it was not protected under the Fourteenth Amendment. As previously decided in ''[[Moore v. East Cleveland]]'',<ref>{{ussc|name=Moore v. City of East Cleveland|volume=431|page=494|pin=|year=1977}}.</ref> liberty interests not "deeply rooted in the nation's history" do not qualify as being a protected liberty interest.
Assisted suicide, the court found, had been frowned upon for centuries and a majority of the states had similar bans on assisted suicide. Rehnquist found the English common law penalties associated with assisted suicide particularly significant. For example, at early common law the state confiscated the property of a person who committed suicide.
Like Blackmun in ''[[Roe v. Wade]]'',<ref>{{ussc|name=Roe v. Wade|volume=410|page=113|pin=|year=1973}}.</ref> Rehnquist used English common law to establish American tradition as a yardstick for determining what rights were "deeply rooted in the nation's history." Rehnquist cited ''Roe v. Wade'' and ''[[Planned Parenthood v. Casey]]''<ref>{{ussc|name=Planned Parenthood v. Casey|link=|volume=505|page=833|pin=|year=1992}}.</ref> in the opinion.
The Court felt that the ban was rational in that it furthered such compelling state interests as the preservation of human life and the protection of the mentally ill and disabled from medical malpractice and coercion. It also prevented those moved to end their lives because of financial or psychological complications. The Court also felt that if it declared physician-assisted suicide a constitutionally protected right, it would start down the path to voluntary and perhaps involuntary euthanasia.
Justice O'Connor concurred. Justices Souter, Ginsburg, Breyer, and Stevens each wrote opinions concurring in the judgment of the court.
In 2008 Washington State voters approved 58%–42% the [[Washington Death with Dignity Act]], which established guidelines for using the services of a physician to terminate one's life.
